tit.e: Otsukegaro (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu, or a person or persons in the post)
Otsukegaro (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu, or a person or persons in the post)
Otsukegaro (a governmental post in the Edo bakufu, or a person or persons in the post)

sen.j: 御附家老（おつけがろう）とは、徳川幕府初期、徳川将軍家血統の貴公子が藩主（大名）になった際に、征夷大将軍より直接命を受けて附属された家老のことである。
sen.e: Otsukegaro indicated a karo (chief retainer) in the early Edo bakufu period who, when kikoshi (a young nobleman) in the linage of the Tokugawa Shogun family became the lord of a domain (daimyo), was appointed directly by Seii taishogun (literally, "the great general who was to subdue the barbarians") for serving the lord.

Otsukegaro is a karo (chief retainer) in the early Edo bakufu period who, when kikoshi (a young nobleman) in the linage of the Tokugawa Shogun family became the lord of a domain (daimyo), was appointed directly by Seii taishogun (literally, "the great general who was to subdue the barbarians") for serving the lord.
sen.cmt: より自然な流れにするため変更しました。indicated → is
sen.e: Otsukegaro is a karo (chief retainer) in the early Edo bakufu period who, when kikoshi (a young nobleman) in the linage of the Tokugawa Shogun family became the lord of a domain (daimyo), was appointed directly by Seii taishogun (literally, "the great general who was to subdue the barbarians") for serving the lord.

sen.j: 江戸時代では、将軍から付けられたので「御」をつけて呼ばれたが、現在では単に附家老（つけがろう）ということが多い。
sen.e: In the Edo period, the character of "御" (indicating a honorific expression) was added to its head, because this karo was appointed by Shogun, but today the more simple term of Tsukegato is used more often instead.

In the Edo period, the character of "御" (indicating a honorific expression) was added to its head, because this karo was appointed by Shogun, but today the more simple term of Tsukegato is used more often instead.

In the Edo period, the character of "御" (indicating a honorific expression) was added to its head, because this karo was appointed by Shogun, but today the more simple term of Tsukegato is used more often instead.

sen.j: 多い場合は十数人付けられたらしいが、通常はそのうちの筆頭家老を指す。
sen.e: As many as more than ten persons were sometimes appointed to the post, but ordinarily this term was used for indicating the head of these karo.
As many as more than ten persons were sometimes appointed to the post, but ordinarily this term was used for indicating the head of these karo.
As many as more than ten persons were sometimes appointed to the post, but ordinarily this term was used for indicating the head of these karo.

sen.j: 徳川御三家の附家老5氏が著名。
sen.e: In particular, five Tsukegaro at the Tokugawa gosanke families (three privileged Tokugawa branch families) are famous.
In particular, five Tsukegaro at the Tokugawa gosanke families (three privileged Tokugawa branch families) are famous.
In particular, five Tsukegaro at the Tokugawa gosanke families (three privileged Tokugawa branch families) are famous.

sen.j: 政務や軍事の補佐を行うとともに、藩主の養育の任も受けていた。
sen.e: Tsukegaro assisted the lord in political affairs and in military affairs, and was also responsible for bringing up the lord.
Tsukegaro assisted the lord in political affairs and in military affairs, and was also responsible for bringing up the lord.
Tsukegaro assisted the lord in political affairs and in military affairs, and was also responsible for bringing up the lord.

sen.j: したがって身分としては、藩主の家来というよりも将軍直属のお目付け役という性格が強い。
sen.e: Therefore, the feature of the status was provided with the characteristics of a watcher-of-lord belonged directly to Shogun rather than a retainer of a lord.
Therefore, the feature of the status were more those of an inspector under the direct supervision of Shogun than those of a retainer of a lord.
sen.cmt: より自然な流れにするため以下のように変更。the feature of the status was provided with the characteristics of a watcher-of-lord belonged directly to Shogun rather than a retainer of a lord.→the feature of the status were more those of an inspector under the direct supervision of Shogun than those of a retainer of a lord.
sen.e: Therefore, the feature of the status were more those of an inspector under the direct supervision of Shogun than those of a retainer of a lord.

sen.j: 時代が下るにしたがって藩ごと、附家老家ごとに考え方に差ができてきた。
sen.e: Over time, the concept of Tsukegaro became to depend on each domain and each Tsukegaro family.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Over time, the concept of Tsukegaro came to depend on each domain and each Tsukegaro family.
sen.cmt: 文法的誤りです。Became to → came to
sen.e: Over time, the concept of Tsukegaro came to depend on each domain and each Tsukegaro family.

sen.j: 藩主に忠実に仕えて将軍家と対抗しようとしたり、逆にいたずらに藩主と対抗したり、藩内で派閥抗争を繰り広げる人物もあったようである。
sen.e: It appears that some Tsukegaro served faithfully to the lord and confronted the shogun family, and some other confronted the lord unnecessarily or engaged in factional strife in the domain.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It appears that some Tsukegaro served faithfully to the lord and confronted the shogun family, and others confronted the lord unnecessarily or engaged in factional strife in the domain.
sen.cmt: 不自然なため変更しました。And some other → others
sen.e: It appears that some Tsukegaro served faithfully to the lord and confronted the shogun family, and others confronted the lord unnecessarily or engaged in factional strife in the domain.

sen.j: 平岩氏（犬山藩12万3000石）
sen.e: The Hiraiwa family (in the Inuyama domain, with a 120,000 koku of rice crop)
The Hiraiwa clan (in the Inuyama domain, with a 120,000 koku of rice crop)
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: The Hiraiwa clan (in the Inuyama domain, with a 120,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 平岩親吉が慶長12年（1607年）閏4月26日より徳川義直の附家老となる。
sen.e: Chikayoshi HIRAIWA was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yoshinao TOKUGAWA on 26th of uruu April, 1607 (in the old calendar).
Chikayoshi HIRAIWA was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yoshinao TOKUGAWA on 26th of April, 1607 (in the old calendar).
Chikayoshi HIRAIWA was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yoshinao TOKUGAWA on 26th of April, 1607 (in the old calendar).

sen.j: 親吉は慶長16年（1611年）12月晦日没し、無嗣により除封された。
sen.e: Chikayoshi died on the last day of December of 1611, and because he had no heir, his properties were confiscated.
Chikayoshi died on the last day of December of 1611, and because he had no heir, his properties were confiscated.
Chikayoshi died on the last day of December of 1611, and because he had no heir, his properties were confiscated.

sen.j: 竹腰氏（今尾藩3万8000石）
sen.e: The TAKEKOSHI family (in the Imao domain, with a 38,000 koku of rice crop)
The TAKEKOSHI clan (in the Imao domain, with a 38,000 koku of rice crop)
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: The TAKEKOSHI clan (in the Imao domain, with a 38,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 竹腰正信が元和 (日本)5年（1619年）より徳川義直の附家老となる。
sen.e: Masanobu TAKEKOSHI was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yoshinao TOKUGAWA in 1619.
Masanobu TAKEKOSHI was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yoshinao TOKUGAWA in 1619.
Masanobu TAKEKOSHI was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yoshinao TOKUGAWA in 1619.

sen.j: 明治元年（1868年）1月24日明治政府により10代竹腰正旧が大名と認められる。
sen.e: On the January 24, 1868, Masatomo TAKETOSHI, the tenth Takekoshi family head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.
On the January 24, 1868, Masatomo TAKETOSHI, the tenth Takekoshi clan head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: On the January 24, 1868, Masatomo TAKETOSHI, the tenth Takekoshi clan head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.

sen.j: 成瀬氏（犬山藩3万5000石）
sen.e: The Naruse family (in the Inuyaka domain, with a 35,000 koku of rice crop)
The Naruse clan (in the Inuyaka domain, with a 35,000 koku of rice crop)
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。

sen.j: 成瀬正成が元和2年（1616年）より徳川義直の附家老となる。
sen.e: Masanari NARUSE was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yoshinao TOKUGAWA in 1616.
Masanari NARUSE was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yoshinao TOKUGAWA in 1616.
Masanari NARUSE was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yoshinao TOKUGAWA in 1616.

sen.j: 明治元年（1868年）1月24日明治政府により9代成瀬正肥が大名と認められる。
sen.e: On the January 24, 1868, Masamitsu Naruse, the ninth Naruse family head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.
On the January 24, 1868, Masamitsu Naruse, the ninth Naruse clan head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.

sen.j: 三河安藤氏（紀伊田辺藩3万8000石）
sen.e: The Mikawa-Ando family (in the Kii-Tanabe domain, with a 38,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 安藤直次が元和5年（1619年）7月19日より徳川頼宣の附家老となる。
sen.e: Naotsugu ANDO was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yorinobu TOKUGAWA on July 19, 1619 (in the old calendar).
Naotsugu ANDO was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yorinobu TOKUGAWA on July 19, 1619 (in the old calendar).
Naotsugu ANDO was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yorinobu TOKUGAWA on July 19, 1619 (in the old calendar).

sen.j: 明治元年（1868年）1月24日明治政府により16代安藤直裕が大名と認められる。
sen.e: On the January 24, 1868 (in the old calendar), Naohiro ANDO, the 16th Ando family head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.

sen.j: 水野氏（紀伊新宮藩3万5000石）
sen.e: The Mizuno family (in the Kii-Shingu domain, with a 35,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 水野重仲が元和5年（1619年）7月19日より徳川頼宣の附家老となる。
sen.e: Shigenaka MIZUNO was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yorinobu TOKUGAWA on July 19, 1619 (in the old calendar).
Shigenaka MIZUNO was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yorinobu TOKUGAWA on July 19, 1619 (in the old calendar).
Shigenaka MIZUNO was appointed to Tsukegaro to Yorinobu TOKUGAWA on July 19, 1619 (in the old calendar).

sen.j: 明治元年（1868年）1月24日明治政府により10代水野忠幹 (紀伊新宮藩主)が大名と認められる。
sen.e: On the January 24, 1868, Tadamoto MIZUNO (the lord of the Kii-Shingu domain), the tenth Mizuno family head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.
On the January 24, 1868, Tadamoto MIZUNO (the lord of the Kii-Shingu domain), the tenth Mizuno clan head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: On the January 24, 1868, Tadamoto MIZUNO (the lord of the Kii-Shingu domain), the tenth Mizuno clan head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.

sen.j: 中山氏（常陸松岡→常陸太田→常陸松岡藩［手綱］2万5000石）
sen.e: The Nakayama family (Hitachi-Matsuoka -> Hitachi-Ota -> the Hitachi-Matsuoka domain (Tazuna), with a 25,000 koku of rice crop)
sen.cmt: 手綱： 意味が調査しきれませんでしたので、発音どおりに訳してあります。
sen.e: The Nakayama clan (Hitachi-Matsuoka -> Hitachi-Ota -> the Hitachi-Matsuoka domain (Tazuna), with a 25,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 中山信吉が徳川頼房の附家老となる。
sen.e: Nobuyoshi NAKAYAMA became Tsukegaro to Yorifusa TOKUGAWA.
Nobuyoshi NAKAYAMA became Tsukegaro to Yorifusa TOKUGAWA.
Nobuyoshi NAKAYAMA became Tsukegaro to Yorifusa TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 明治元年（1868年）1月24日明治政府により14代中山信徴が大名と認められる。
sen.e: On the January 24, 1868, Nobuaki NAKAYAMA, the 14th Nakayama family head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.
On the January 24, 1868, Nobuaki NAKAYAMA, the 14th Nakayama clan head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: On the January 24, 1868, Nobuaki NAKAYAMA, the 14th Nakayama clan head was recognized as a daimyo by the Meiji government.

sen.j: 水野氏（安房・上総国内 石高不明）
sen.e: The Mizuno family (in the Awa/Kazusa province, with the amount of rice crop unknown)
The Mizuno clan (in the Awa/Kazusa province, with the amount of rice crop unknown)
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: The Mizuno clan (in the Awa/Kazusa province, with the amount of rice crop unknown)

sen.j: 水野分長が徳川頼房の附家老となる。
sen.e: Wakenaga MIZUNO became Tsukegaro to Yorifusa TOKUGAWA.
Wakenaga MIZUNO became Tsukegaro to Yorifusa TOKUGAWA.
Wakenaga MIZUNO became Tsukegaro to Yorifusa TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 分長は元和9年（1623年）没し、無嗣により除封された。
sen.e: Wakenaga died in 1623, and because he had no heir, his properties were confiscated.
Wakenaga died in 1623, and because he had no heir, his properties were confiscated.
Wakenaga died in 1623, and because he had no heir, his properties were confiscated.

tit.j: 御三家以外の御附家老
tit.e: Otsukegaro other than those at the gosanke families
Otsukegaro other than those at the gosanke families
Otsukegaro other than those at the gosanke families

sen.j: 本多氏（越前府中(越前市)3万9千石）
sen.e: The Honda family (in Echizen-fuchu (present Echizen City), with a 39,000 koku of rice crop)
The Honda clan (in Echizen-fuchu (present Echizen City), with a 39,000 koku of rice crop)
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: The Honda clan (in Echizen-fuchu (present Echizen City), with a 39,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 本多富正（本多重次の甥）が慶長6年（1601年）に徳川家康の子、結城秀康の越前藩一国68万石に附家老として従う。
sen.e: Tomimasa HONDA (a nephew of Shigetsugu HONDA) went to the 680,000-koku Echizen domain of Hideyasu YUKI, a son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, accompanying him as Tsukegaro.
Tomimasa HONDA (a nephew of Shigetsugu HONDA) became the Tsukegaro of the 680,000-koku Echizen domain of Hideyasu YUKI, a son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
sen.cmt: より自然な流れにするため変更しました。went to the 680,000-koku Echizen domain of Hideyasu YUKI, a son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, accompanying him as Tsukegaro→became the Tsukegaro of the 680,000-koku Echizen domain of Hideyasu YUKI, a son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.
sen.e: Tomimasa HONDA (a nephew of Shigetsugu HONDA) became the Tsukegaro of the 680,000-koku Echizen domain of Hideyasu YUKI, a son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 以降幕末まで越前家筆頭家老として代々執政を行う。
sen.e: Until the end of the bakufu after that, the head of the family managed the governmental affairs of the domain as the head Karo of the Echizen family.
Until the end of the bakufu after that, he managed the governmental affairs of the domain as the head Karo of the Echizen family.
sen.cmt: より自然にするため変更しました。the head of the family → he
sen.e: Until the end of the bakufu after that, he managed the governmental affairs of the domain as the head Karo of the Echizen family.

sen.j: 当初は鬼作左・本多重次自身、もしくはその子を望まれていたのだが、陪臣扱いを嫌って甥（実父は死別、重次が養育）を代わりに立てたとも言われている。
sen.e: It is also said that initially, Onisakuza, or Shigetsugu HONDA, himself, or his son was desired for the post, but he recommended his nephew (whose father had died and was brought up by Shigetusgu) instead because he disliked for being handled as a baishin (a retainer of a shogun's direct retainer).
sen.cmt: 後列（消去済み）と合体してあります。
sen.e: It is also said that initially, Onisakuza, or Shigetsugu HONDA, himself, or his son was desired for the post, but he recommended his nephew (whose father had died and was brought up by Shigetsugu) instead because he disliked for being handled as a baishin (a retainer of a shogun's direct retainer).
sen.cmt: 誤字のため変更しました。Shigetusgu→Shigetsugu
sen.e: It is also said that initially, Onisakuza, or Shigetsugu HONDA, himself, or his son was desired for the post, but he recommended his nephew (whose father had died and was brought up by Shigetsugu) instead because he disliked for being handled as a baishin (a retainer of a shogun's direct retainer).

sen.j: 松平忠直の改易の際は独立大名化を打診された。
sen.e: When a Kaieki punishment (forfeit rank of Samurai and properties) was administered to Tadanao MATSUDAIRA, he was inquired about whether would like to become an independent daimyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When a Kaieki punishment (forfeit rank of Samurai and properties) was administered to Tadanao MATSUDAIRA, he was wanted for the position of an independent daimyo.
sen.cmt: 構文的誤りのため変更しました。he was inquired about whether would like to become an independent daimyo.→he was wanted for the position of an independent daimyo.
sen.e: When a Kaieki punishment (forfeit rank of Samurai and properties) was administered to Tadanao MATSUDAIRA, he was wanted for the position of an independent daimyo.

sen.j: しかしながら、越前松平家（藩初代の秀康）への恩義があると言って、正式な独立を固辞した。
sen.e: However, he firmly declined to become officially independent saying that he was under an obligation of the Mtsudaira family (Hideyasu, the first lord of the domain).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, he firmly declined to become officially independent saying that he was under an obligation of the Mtsudaira family (Hideyasu, the first lord of the domain).
sen.cmt: 誤字のため変更しました。Mtsudaira →Matsudaira
sen.e: However, he firmly declined to become officially independent saying that he was under an obligation of the Mtsudaira family (Hideyasu, the first lord of the domain).

sen.j: 一方、幕府では大名待遇を受けていた。
sen.e: On the other hand, he was treated as a daimyo in the bakufu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: On the other hand, he was treated as a daimyo in the bakufu.
On the other hand, he was treated as a daimyo in the bakufu.

sen.j: 大名行列を組んでの参勤交代、その際の長刀を掲げたままでの、または駕籠に乗ったままでの関所通過の許可、江戸城内では柳の間詰め（四位以下の大名並）だった。
sen.e: For example, in the Daimyo-gyoretsu procession (feudal lord's costumed procession) in the Sankinkotai system (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo), he was allowed to pass sekisho (checking stations) with his long sword being held up or without getting off his palanquin, and he waited in the willow room (together with other daimyo ranked at Shii (the fourth rank) or lower).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: For example, in the Daimyo-gyoretsu procession (feudal lord's costumed procession) in the Sankinkotai system (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo), he was allowed to pass sekisho (checking stations) with his long sword being held up or without getting off his palanquin, and he waited in the willow room (together with other daimyo ranked at Shii (the fourth rank) or lower).

For example, in the Daimyo-gyoretsu procession (feudal lord's costumed procession) in the Sankinkotai system (a system under which feudal lords in the Edo period were required to spend every other year in residence in Edo), he was allowed to pass sekisho (checking stations) with his long sword being held up or without getting off his palanquin, and he waited in the willow room (together with other daimyo ranked at Shii (the fourth rank) or lower).

sen.j: 幕府より浅草（後に本所）に江戸屋敷を拝領している。
sen.e: An Edo residence was bestowed on him by the bakufu in Asakusa (later Honjo)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: An Edo residence was bestowed on him by the bakufu in Asakusa (later Honjo)
An Edo residence was bestowed on him by the bakufu in Asakusa (later Honjo)

sen.j: 将軍家の慶弔行事では諸大名と並んで献上を行った。
sen.e: In the celebrating or morning occasions at the shogun family, he made presents together with other daimyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: In the celebrating or morning occasions at the shogun family, he made presents together with other daimyo.
In the celebrating or morning occasions at the shogun family, he made presents together with other daimyo.

sen.j: 江戸在勤の折は将軍に必ず御目見え、拝領物を頂く慣例となっており、その待遇は独立大名並であった。
sen.e: When he worked in Edo, it was customary that he always had an audience with the shogun and received a present from the shogun, showing that he was treated almost as an independent daimyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When he worked in Edo, it was customary that he presented himself in front of the shogun and received a present from the shogun, showing that he was treated almost as an independent daimyo.
sen.cmt: より自然な流れにするため変更しました。it was customary that he presented himself in front of the shogun
sen.e: When he worked in Edo, it was customary that he presented himself in front of the shogun and received a present from the shogun, showing that he was treated almost as an independent daimyo.

sen.j: しかし廃藩置県後に本多家は陪臣として扱われ、士族とされる
sen.e: However, in the Haihan-chiken reform (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures), the Honda family was treated as a baishin (a retainer of shogun's retainer) and was designated as shizoku (family or person with samurai ancestors).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, in the Haihan-chiken reform (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures), the Honda family was treated as a baishin (a retainer of shogun's retainer) and was designated as shizoku (family or person with samurai ancestors).

However, in the Haihan-chiken reform (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures), the Honda family was treated as a baishin (a retainer of shogun's retainer) and was designated as shizoku (family or person with samurai ancestors).

sen.j: が、旧領民および旧家臣らがこれを不服として1870年（明治3年）に武生騒動を起こし、明治12年に華族に列せられ、1884年（明治17年）に男爵となった。
sen.e: Being reluctant to accept this situation, people in his former territory and his former retainers caused the Takefu disturbance in 1870, and he was included in Kazoku (peers) in 1879, being awarded the Danshaku status in 1884.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Being reluctant to accept this situation, people in his former territory and his former retainers caused the Takefu disturbance in 1870, and he was included in Kazoku (peerage) in 1879, being awarded the status of baron in 1884.
sen.cmt: 華族の訳としてはpeerageが一般的かと思いましたので変更しました。男爵もbaronが定訳なので変更しました。
sen.e: Being reluctant to accept this situation, people in his former territory and his former retainers caused the Takefu disturbance in 1870, and he was included in Kazoku (peerage) in 1879, being awarded the status of baron in 1884.

sen.j: 本多氏（越前丸岡4万石）
sen.e: The Honda family (in Echizen-Maruoka, with a 40,000 koku of rice crop)
The Honda clan (in Echizen-Maruoka, with a 40,000 koku of rice crop)
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: The Honda clan (in Echizen-Maruoka, with a 40,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 本多成重（本多重次の子）は幕臣として5000石を食んでいたが、慶長18年（1613年）松平忠直（福井藩75万石）付の附家老となり、若年の忠直を前述の本多富正と共に支え、大坂の役などに活躍。
sen.e: Narishige HONDA (a son of Shigetsugu HONDA), who had earned a 5,000 koku of rice crop as a shogun's retainer, became Tsukegato to Tadanao MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the 750,000-koku Fukui domain) in 1613, supported young Tadanao together with Tomimasa HONDA, and played an important role, for example, in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka)

Narishige HONDA (a son of Shigetsugu HONDA), who had earned a 5,000 koku of rice crop as a shogun's retainer, became Tsukegato to Tadanao MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the 750,000-koku Fukui domain) in 1613, supported young Tadanao together with Tomimasa HONDA, and played an important role, for example, in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka)

Narishige HONDA (a son of Shigetsugu HONDA), who had earned a 5,000 koku of rice crop as a shogun's retainer, became Tsukegato to Tadanao MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the 750,000-koku Fukui domain) in 1613, supported young Tadanao together with Tomimasa HONDA, and played an important role, for example, in Osaka no Eki (The Siege of Osaka)

sen.j: 一説には重次が、送り込んだ甥の出世を見て、実子を福井藩にねじ込んだ（なので新参なのに石高が富正より少し高い）、とも。
sen.e: According to a theory, it is also said that, seeing that his nephew whom he recommended for the post was successful, Shigetugu had his son occupied the post as well forcibly (therefore, his son earned slightly more amount of rice crop than Tomimasa, though having gotten the post later).

According to a theory, it is also said that, seeing that his nephew whom he recommended for the post was successful, Shigetugu had his son occupy the post as well forcibly (therefore, his son earned slightly more amount of rice crop than Tomimasa, though having gotten the post later).
sen.cmt: 文法的誤りのため変更しました。Shigetugu had his son occupied the post as well forcibly (therefore, his son earned slightly more amount of rice crop than Tomimasa, though having gotten the post later).→Shigetugu had his son occupy the post as well forcibly (therefore, his son earned a slightly bigger amount of rice crop than Tomimasa, though he took up the post later).
sen.e: According to a theory, it is also said that, seeing that his nephew whom he recommended for the post was successful, Shigetugu had his son occupy the post as well forcibly (therefore, his son earned slightly more amount of rice crop than Tomimasa, though having gotten the post later).

sen.j: 忠直が後に改易・流罪となった際、成重（丸岡藩）は独立、大名となった。
sen.e: When a kaieki punishment was administered to Tadanao and he was exiled, Narishishige (in the Maruoka domain) became an independent daimyo.
When a kaieki punishment was administered to Tadanao and he was exiled, Narishishige (in the Maruoka domain) became an independent daimyo.
When a kaieki punishment was administered to Tadanao and he was exiled, Narishishige (in the Maruoka domain) became an independent daimyo.

sen.j: 小笠原氏（尾張犬山１万石）
sen.e: Ogasawara family (in Owari-Inuyama, with a 10,000 koku of rice crop)
Ogasawara clan (in Owari-Inuyama, with a 10,000 koku of rice crop)
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: Ogasawara clan (in Owari-Inuyama, with a 10,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 小笠原吉次が慶長5年（1600年）11月より松平忠吉（清洲藩52万石）の附家老となる。
sen.e: Kichiji Ogasawara became a Tsukegaro to Tadayoshi MATSUDAIRA (in the 520,000-koku Kiyosu domain) in November of 1600 (in the old calendar).
Kichiji Ogasawara became a Tsukegaro to Tadayoshi MATSUDAIRA (in the 520,000-koku Kiyosu domain) in November of 1600 (in the old calendar).
Kichiji Ogasawara became a Tsukegaro to Tadayoshi MATSUDAIRA (in the 520,000-koku Kiyosu domain) in November of 1600 (in the old calendar).

sen.j: 忠吉が慶長12年（1607年）3月5日没し、無嗣により除封された。
sen.e: Tadayoshi died on April 1, 1607, and because he had no heir, his properties was confiscated.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Tadayoshi died on April 1, 1607, and because he had no heir, his properties was confiscated.
Tadayoshi died on April 1, 1607, and because he had no heir, his properties was confiscated.

sen.j: そのため、吉次は慶長12年（1607年）閏4月29日佐倉藩へ転封され大名となった。
sen.e: Therefore, Kichiji's territory was changed to the Sakura domain on June 23, 1607, becoming a daimyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, Kichiji's territory was changed to the Sakura domain on June 23, 1607, becoming a daimyo.
Therefore, Kichiji's territory was changed to the Sakura domain on June 23, 1607, becoming a daimyo.

sen.j: 能見松平家（三条藩2万石）
sen.e: The Nomi-Matsudaira family (in the Sanjo domain, with a 20,000 koku of rice crop)
The Nomi-Matsudaira family (in the Sanjo domain, with a 20,000 koku of rice crop)
The Nomi-Matsudaira family (in the Sanjo domain, with a 20,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 松平重勝が慶長19年（1614年）より松平忠輝（高田藩60万石）の附家老となる。
sen.e: Shigekatsu MATSUDAIRA became a Tsukegaro to Tadateru MATSUDAIRA (in the 600,000-koku Takada domain) in 1614.
Shigekatsu MATSUDAIRA became a Tsukegaro to Tadateru MATSUDAIRA (in the 600,000-koku Takada domain) in 1614.
Shigekatsu MATSUDAIRA became a Tsukegaro to Tadateru MATSUDAIRA (in the 600,000-koku Takada domain) in 1614.

sen.j: 忠輝が元和2年（1616年）7月5日不行跡により除封された。
sen.e: Tadateru's properties were confiscated due to his misconducts on August 17, 1616.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Tadateru's properties were confiscated due to his misconducts on August 17, 1616.
Tadateru's properties were confiscated due to his misconducts on August 17, 1616.

sen.j: そのため、元和3年（1617年）12月関宿藩へ転封され大名となった。
sen.e: Therefore, Shigekatsu's territory was changed to the Sekiyado domain in December of 1617 (in the old calendar), becoming a daimyo.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Therefore, Shigekatsu's territory was changed to the Sekiyado domain in December of 1617 (in the old calendar), becoming a daimyo.

sen.j: 鳥居氏（谷村藩3万5000石）
sen.e: The Torii family (in the Yamura domain, with a 35,000 koku of rice crop)
The Torii clan (in the Yamura domain, with a 35,000 koku of rice crop)
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: The Torii clan (in the Yamura domain, with a 35,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 鳥居成次が元和2年（1616年）より徳川忠長（甲府藩20万石→駿府藩50万石）の附家老となる。
sen.e: Naritsugu Torii became a Tsukegaro to Tadanaga TOKUGAWA (in the 200,000-koku Kofu domain -> the 500,000-koku Sumpu domain) in 1616.
Naritsugu Torii became a Tsukegaro to Tadanaga TOKUGAWA (in the 200,000-koku Kofu domain -> the 500,000-koku Sumpu domain) in 1616.

sen.j: 2代鳥居忠房は寛永9年（1632年）10月28日忠長に連座し除封された。
sen.e: The properties of Tadafusa TORII, the second Torii family head, was confiscated on December 9, 1632 due to having been implicated in Tadanaga's misconduct.
The properties of Tadafusa TORII, the second Torii clanhead, was confiscated on December 9, 1632 due to having been implicated in Tadanaga's misconduct.
sen.cmt: 「氏」はclanと訳す方が一般的だと思うので変更しました。
sen.e: The properties of Tadafusa TORII, the second Torii clanhead, was confiscated on December 9, 1632 due to having been implicated in Tadanaga's misconduct.

sen.j: 朝倉宣正が寛永元年（1624年）より徳川忠長の附家老となる。
sen.e: Nobumasa Asakura became a Tsukegaro to Tadanaga TOKUGAWA in 1624.
Nobumasa Asakura became a Tsukegaro to Tadanaga TOKUGAWA in 1624.

sen.j: 寛永9年（1632年）忠長に連座し除封された。
sen.e: His properties were confiscated in 1632 due to having been implicated in Tadanaga's misconduct.

sen.e: The Inaba family (in the Itoigawa domain, with a 20,000 koku of rice crop)

sen.j: 稲葉正成が元和4年（1618年）2月より松平忠昌（越後高田25万石）の附家老となる。
sen.e: Masanari INABA became a Tsukegaro to Tadamasa MATSUDAIRA (in the 250,000-koku Echigo-Takada domain) in February of 1618 (in the old calendar).
Masanari INABA became a Tsukegaro to Tadamasa MATSUDAIRA (in the 250,000-koku Echigo-Takada domain) in February of 1618 (in the old calendar).

sen.j: 正成は元和9年（1623年）退去したため除封された（のち寛永4年(1627年)2月に真岡藩2万石の大名となる）。
sen.e: Because Masanari abandoned his post, his properties were confiscated (later, becoming the daimyo of the 20,000-koku Maoka domain in February of 1627 (in the old calendar)).
Because Masanari abandoned his post in1623, his properties were confiscated (later, becoming the daimyo of the 20,000-koku Maoka domain in February of 1627 (in the old calendar)).
sen.cmt: 元和9年（1623年）、訳漏れのため、in 1623を追加。
sen.e: Because Masanari abandoned his post in1623, his properties were confiscated (later, becoming the daimyo of the 20,000-koku Maoka domain in February of 1627 (in the old calendar)).
